name: King John's Castle
tagline: Limerick's most iconic landmark on King's Island
managedBy: Limerick City and County Council - Discover Limerick

description.short: Located at the heart of Limerick's medieval quarter, King John's Castle brings to life over 800 years of dramatic local history on the banks of the River Shannon.
description.full: Step inside the walls of Limerick's most iconic landmark on King's Island in the heart of medieval Limerick City. King John's Castle brings to life over 800 years of dramatic local history. Discover the stories of ruthless King John, the noble knights, and rebellious natives. Explore the spacious outdoor courtyard where you'll get a sense of the bustling activity that took place many years ago. Venture into the visitor centre with state of the art interpretive activities and exhibitions. 21st century touch screen technology, 3D models and discovery drawers are among the exciting techniques that will connect you to tales of siege and warfare. Visitors will love the dazzling array of computer generated animations and ghostly projections as they travel back through time. The site has been occupied for over 1000 years, with a turbulent history dating back to Viking times and having undergone several sieges, battles and triumphs throughout its long history.
description.history: The site on which King John's Castle stands has been occupied for over 1000 years. Viking settlers established a fortified settlement on King's Island around 922 AD. Following the Norman invasion of Ireland, King John of England ordered the construction of a royal castle on this strategic location overlooking the River Shannon between 1200-1210. The castle was built to command the crossing point of the Shannon and protect the newly conquered Norman settlement. The fortress features five massive drum towers and impressive curtain walls. Throughout the medieval period, the castle served as the center of English administrative and military power in the region. It endured numerous sieges during the Irish Confederate Wars in the 1640s and during the Williamite War in the 1690s. The castle underwent a major conservation and development project completed in 2013, opening a new €5.5 million visitor experience that brings together the castle's remarkable archaeology and 21st century technology.
description.significance: One of Ireland's best-preserved Norman castles and Limerick's signature landmark, representing over 800 years of Irish history from Viking settlement through Norman conquest to modern times. The castle is a centerpiece of Limerick's Medieval Quarter.

directions.general: Located on King's Island in Limerick City centre, on the banks of the River Shannon
directions.byCar: Limerick City is accessible via the M7 from Dublin (2.5 hours), N20 from Cork (1 hour), and N18 from Galway (1 hour). Public parking available nearby at Arthur's Quay Shopping Centre and on-street parking
directions.byBus: Limerick City is served by Bus Éireann services from all major cities. The castle is a 5-minute walk from Limerick Bus Station
directions.byTrain: Limerick Colbert Station is approximately 1.5km from the castle (15-minute walk or short taxi ride). Regular services from Dublin, Cork, Galway and other cities
directions.parking: Public car parks nearby at Arthur's Quay and on-street parking available. Coach parking can be arranged

visitingInformation.averageVisitDuration: 1.5-2 hours (recommended 2-3 hours to fully enjoy all experiences)
visitingInformation.adviceForVisitors: Book tickets online in advance to guarantee entry. Allow 2-3 hours minimum to fully explore the castle, exhibitions, and courtyard activities. Comfortable walking shoes recommended for climbing towers. The café offers stunning views of the courtyard and River Shannon - perfect for refreshments. Special events including concerts are held throughout the summer months.

accessibility.accessibilityNotes: The ground floor exhibition areas and courtyard are wheelchair accessible. The visitor centre, café, shop, and toilets are all accessible. However, access to the castle towers involves steep medieval spiral staircases and is not suitable for visitors with mobility issues. Please contact in advance to discuss specific accessibility needs.

historicalSignificance.vikingEra: The site was originally settled by Vikings around 922 AD who established a fortified settlement on King's Island at the strategic crossing point of the River Shannon.
historicalSignificance.normanEra: Built 1200-1210 on orders of King John of England as a royal fortress to command the Shannon crossing and protect the Norman settlement. Features five massive drum towers and curtain walls.
historicalSignificance.medievalPeriod: Served as the center of English administrative and military power in the region throughout the medieval period.
historicalSignificance.confederateWars: Endured sieges during the Irish Confederate Wars (1640s) when it was used as an arsenal under Irish forces.
historicalSignificance.williamiteWar: Further sieges during the Williamite War (1690s) as control of Limerick changed hands.
historicalSignificance.modernEra: €5.5 million conservation and development project completed in 2013, creating a world-class visitor experience combining archaeology and 21st century technology.
